{{Infobox single | Name = Venus | Cover = Shocking Blue Venus.jpg | Artist = [[Shocking Blue]] In spite of the name mentioned on this cover, the band's name was [[Shocking Blue]], without "The". | from Album = [[At Home (Shocking Blue album)|At Home]] | B-side = "Hot Sand" | Released = October 2, 1969 | Format = 7" vinyl | Recorded = [[1969 in music|1969]] | Genre = [[Rock and Roll|Rock]], [[psychedelic rock]] | Length = 3:06 | Label = Pink Elephant, Metronome, [[Colossus Records|Colossus]], Poplandia, Joker, Yugoton | Writer = Robbie van Leeuwen | Producer = Robbie van Leeuwen | Certification = Gold ([[RIAA]]) | Last single = "Lucy Brown Is Back In Town"
(1968) | This single = "'''Venus'''"
(1969) | Next single = "[[Mighty Joe]]"
(1969) }} "'''Venus'''" is a 1969 song by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] band [[Shocking Blue]] which the group took to number one in the U.S. and five countries across Europe in 1970. When covered by girl group [[Bananarama]], the song returned to number one in the U.S. and topped the charts in six other countries around the world in 1986. The composition has been featured in numerous films, television shows and commercials, and covered dozens of times by artists around the world. ==Shocking Blue== Released in late 1969 as a single from the album ''At Home'', Shocking Blue's single reached number one on the [[Billboard Hot 100]] on February 7, 1970. [[RIAA]] certification came on January 28, 1970 for selling over one million copies in the U.S., garnering a [[music recording sales certification|gold record]]. The song's lead vocals are performed by [[Mariska Veres]]. The song's music and lyrics are written by [[Robbie van Leeuwen]], the band's [[guitar]]ist, [[sitar]]ist and background vocalist, who also produced, along with record producer Jerry Ross. Van Leeuwen used "The Banjo Song", an arrangement of "[[Oh! Susanna]]" on a 1963 album by [[Tim Rose#The Big Three|The Big 3]], as main inspiration; the bassline, riffs and melody are almost exactly the same.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} However, The Big 3 never claimed plagiarism. "Venus" was [[remix]]ed and re-released by dance [[Record producer|producers]] The BHF (Bisiach Hornbostel Ferrucci) Team in May 1990, scoring the group a Top 10 hit in the UK and Australia 21 years after the release of the original. The remix featured a [[hip house]] rhythm and [[Sampling (music)|samples]]. An instrumental version was also released independently under the producer's alias "Don Pablo's Animals". The instrumental version (credited only to Don Pablos Animals - without referencing Shocking Blue) became the highest charting version of the song. {{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 164}} The single began with a sample from [[James Brown]]'s 1988 hit "The Payback Mix (Part One)". This release of "Venus" peaked at #4 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] and #8 in Australia in 1990. ===Shocking Blue version in popular culture=== * Included in the film ''[[The Brady Bunch Movie]]'' * Included in the film ''[[Grumpier Old Men]]'' * Included in the film ''Zonder Zelda'' * Included in the film ''[[Remember the Titans]]'' * Parodied by [[the Muppets]] for a television [[public service announcement]] about the [[V-chip]] and TV ratings. * A Caveman-Style Musical version appears in ''[[Croc 2]]'', as the theme for "Venus fly Von Trappe". * [[Sharon Watts]] (played by [[Letitia Dean]]) sang "Venus" in an episode of ''[[EastEnders]]''. * [[D.J. Tanner]] ([[Candace Cameron]]) and her best friend [[Kimmy Gibbler]] ([[Andrea Barber]]) sang "Venus" with [[Jesse Katsopolis]] ([[John Stamos]]) in a season one episode of ''[[Full House]]'' in which he taught them how to succeed in a band. * A Spanish version was played on the ''[[Prison Break]]'' episode "[[Good Fences (Prison Break episode)|Good Fences]]". * Morissey, the former lead singer of The Smiths, used the Shocking Blue music video for "Venus", in a pre-concert video shown during his 2009 tour. *The song is used in the opening sequence of the 2008 film ''[[Otis (film)|Otis]]''. *The song was used in the March 11, 2009 episode of ''[[Life on Mars (U.S. TV series)|Life on Mars]]'' when a group of flight attendants arrive at an airport bar. *Twin sisters, Sarah & Casey Hunter sang Venus, in the Sugar & Spice book, Stuck in the 80's. === Shocking Blue version on the charts === {| class="wikitable" !align="left"|Chart (1970) !align="left"|Peak
position |- |align="left"|U.S. Billboard Hot 100 |align="center"|1 |- |align="left"|Belgium singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |align="left"|French singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |align="left"|German singles chart |align="center"|2 |- |align="left"|Italy singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |align="left"|Spanish singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |align="left"|Japan Oricon Singles Chart |align="center"|2 |- |align="left"|Dutch Top 40 Single Chart |align="center"|3 |- |align="left"|[[UK Singles Chart]]{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 496}} |align="center"|8 |- |} ==Bananarama version== {{Infobox single | Name = Venus | Cover = Banana_v.jpg | Artist = [[Bananarama]] | from Album = [[True Confessions (album)|True Confessions]] | B-side = "White Train" | Released = May 30, [[1986 in music|1986]] | Format = 7" vinyl, 12" vinyl | Recorded = December 1985 | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[disco]], [[New Wave music|new wave]] | Length = 3:51 (Album Version)
3:40 (Single Version) | Label = [[London Records]] | Writer = Robbie van Leeuwen | Producer = [[Stock Aitken Waterman]] | Certification = [[Gold record|Gold]] ([[RIAA]]) | Last single = "[[Do Not Disturb (song)|Do Not Disturb]]"
(1985) | This single = "'''Venus'''"
(1986) | Next single = "[[More Than Physical]]"
(1986) {{Extra music sample|type=single |filename=bananarama venus.ogg |format=[[Ogg]] |title="Venus"}} }} "Venus" had been a part of Bananarama's repertoire for several years before they actually recorded it. The team's three members, [[Sara Dallin]], [[Siobhan Fahey]], and [[Keren Woodward]], had the idea of turning the song into a [[dance music]] tune, but they were met with resistance from their producers at the time, [[Jolley & Swain|Steve Jolley and Tony Swain]]. Bananarama brought the idea to the production trio of [[Stock Aitken Waterman]], and it became Bananarama's first collaboration with them. Dallin, Fahey, and Woodward had nearly completed recording their third album, titled ''[[True Confessions (album)|True Confessions]],'' with Jolley and Swain. Stock, Aitken and Waterman also resisted the idea because they believed that "Venus" would not make a good dance record. After persistence by the women, SAW relented, and the result was a worldwide smash. Bananarama's "Venus" went to number one in the U.S., Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Switzerland, Mexico, and South Africa. It hit number two in Germany and Hong Kong and was a top ten success in Italy, Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Netherlands, Sweden, Colombia, Norway, Portugal, Spain, and their native UK (#8 on [[UK Singles Chart]]). It also went to number one for two weeks on the [[Hot Dance Music/Club Play|U.S. Dance]] chart. The collaboration on "Venus" led Bananarama and SAW to work together on the group's follow-up album ''[[Wow! (Bananarama album)|Wow!]]'' the following year. A new mix of the track appeared as b-side to the 1989 limited release "Megarama '89" in Germany and France. Bananarama has since re-recorded the track for their 2001 album ''[[Exotica (Bananarama album)|Exotica]]'' and it was later [[remix]]ed by [[Marc Almond]], with re-recorded vocals, and included on their 2005 album ''[[Drama (Bananarama album)|Drama]]''. ===Music video=== The [[music video]] for the song received extensive play on [[MTV]] and video channels across the world, and presented Bananarama in various costumes, including a [[Succubi|she-devil]], a French [[temptress]], a [[vampiress]], and several [[Greek mythology|Grecian]] [[goddess]]es. In one sequence of the video, ''[[The Birth of Venus (Botticelli)|The Birth of Venus]],'' the painting by [[Sandro Botticelli]], was reenacted. The video marked a pivotal shift towards a more glamorous and sexual image for the girls that contrasted with the tomboyish style in their earlier work. Choreography by [[Bruno Tonioli]]. Music video directed by [[Peter Care]]. ===Track Listings=== ; 7" single NANA10 #"Venus" 3:30 #"White Train" 3:50 #:S.Dallin/S. Fahey/K. Woodward/P. Bishop/P. Seymour ; 12" single NANX10 #"Venus" (Extended version) 7:23 #"Venus" (Dub) 8:15 #"White Train" 3:50 ; 2nd 12" single NANXR10 #"Venus" (The Hellfire Mix) 9:20 #:Remixed by Ian Levine #"Venus" (Hellfire Dub) 6:55 #"White Train" 3:50 ; 3rd 12" single NAXRR10 #"Venus" (The Fire And Brimstone Mix) 6:35 #:Remixed by Stock, Aitken & Waterman #"Venus" (Hellfire Dub) 6:55 #"White Train" 3:50 ; US 12" maxi-single 886 088-1 #"Venus" (The Hellfire Mix) 9:20 #"Venus" (The Fire & Brimstone mix) 6:55 #"Venus" (Extended version) 7:23 #"Venus" (Dub) 8:25 ; CD video single #"Venus" (Extended version) 7:23 #"True Confessions" (Edit) 4:09 #"[[A Trick of the Night]]" (Edit) 4:07 #"[[More Than Physical]]" (UK Single version) 3:40 ; Other versions #"Venus" (The Greatest Remix Edit) 3:40 #:Found on the 1989 UK CD single "[[Cruel Summer '89]]", Remixed by Phil Harding and Ian Curnow #"Venus" (The Greatest Remix) 7:43 #:Found on the 1989 German CD single "[[Megarama '89]]", Remixed by Phil Harding and Ian Curnow #"Venus" (2001 version) #:Found on the album ''[[Exotica (Bananarama album)|Exotica]]'' #"Venus" (Marc Almond's Hi-NRG Showgirls mix) 6:02 #:Found on the 2005 album ''[[Drama (Bananarama album)|Drama]]'', Remixed by [[Marc Almond]] #"Venus" (From Soundtrack Sugar & Spice: Stuck in the 80's) ===Personnel=== '''Bananarama''' *[[Sara Dallin]] - Vocals *[[Siobhan Fahey]] - Vocals *[[Keren Woodward]] - Vocals '''Additional personnel''' *Andrew Biscomb - Sleeve design *Peter Barrett - Sleeve design ===Bananarama version in popular culture=== * Included in the film ''[[Romy and Michele's High School Reunion]]'' * In the film ''[[American Wedding]]'' the song is featured in a dancing scene in a gay bar.http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0328828/soundtrack * The music video was viewed and commented on by [[Beavis and Butthead]]. * The song is a major part of [[Global Gillette|Gillette's]] [[advertising campaign]] for their [[product line|line]] of "Venus" female [[razors]]. * It was the first ever song which a contestant on the UK version of ''[[Don't Forget the Lyrics]]'' failed to complete. * Canadian teen drama series program ''[[Degrassi: The Next Generation]],'' which names each episode after an '80s hit song, named a two-part installment after the song. * An episode of ''[[American Dad]]'' ("Moon over Isla Island", Season 5 Ep2) plays the song when Roger suggests changing the name of the country of Isla to Bananarama, with "Venus" as its national anthem. * The song was used for the goals segment of [[Don Cherry's Rock'Em Sock'em Hockey]] (1989). ===Bananarama version on the charts=== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" !Chart (1986) !Peak
position |- |Australian singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |Austrian singles chart |align="center"|7 |- |Belgian singles chart |align="center"|3 |- |Canadian singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |Denmark singles chart |align="center"|14 |- |Dutch singles chart |align="center"|4 |- |Finland singles chart |align="center"|5 |- |French singles chart |align="center"|4 |- |German singles chart |align="center"|2 |- |Irish singles chart |align="center"|12 |- |Italian singles chart |align="center"|4 |- |Japan singles chart |align="center"|43 |- |} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" !Chart (1986) !Peak
position |- |New Zealand singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |Norway singles chart |align="center"|4 |- |South African singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |Spanish singles chart |align="center"|7 |- |Swedish singles chart |align="center"|9 |- |Swiss singles chart |align="center"|1 |- |[[UK Singles Chart]]{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 41}} |align="center"|8 |- |U.S. Billboard Hot 100 |align="center"|1 |- |U.S. Hot Dance Club Play |align="center"|1 |- |} {{col-end}} ==Other cover versions== * In 1969, [[Bulgarians|Bulgarian]] singer [[Lili Ivanova]] recorded her version of the song, called "Venera" (Bulgarian: "ÐÐµÐ½ÐµÑÐ°"). * In 1970, [[Greeks|Greek]] band [[Olympians (band)|Olympians]] recorded the song "To koritsi tou Mai" (Greek: "Î¤Î¿ ÎºÎ¿ÏÎ¯ÏÏÎ¹ ÏÎ¿Ï ÎÎ¬Î·", meaning ''"Girl of May"'') with the melody of "Venus" and lyrics written by Sevi Tiliakou. * In late 1976 the Stockley Sisters, a South African duo, took their recording of the song to number 5 on the South African singles chart. * On July 18, 1981, Dutch act [[Stars on 45]] reached #1 in the U.S. with a [[Stars on 45 Medley|medley]] including the opening guitar riff from "Venus". With the original Shocking Blue and the later Bananarama cover both going to #1 on the [[Billboard Hot 100]], this arguably made it the only song in that chart's history to hit #1 by three different artists, though the Stars on 45 medley only included a portion. * A cover was released by then [[J-pop]] [[Japanese idol|idol singer]] [[Yoko Nagayama]] in 1986, which became her first big hit. * In 1986, [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] included the Bananarama version in his polka medley "[[Polka Party! (song)|Polka Party!]]" from [[Polka Party!|the album of the same name]]. * A version of the song by [[The Chipettes]], done in their signature style, was included on the album ''[[The Chipmunks and The Chipettes: Born to Rock|Born to Rock]]'' in 1988. They would also cover the Bananarama version for the 1998 album ''[[The A-Files: Alien Songs]]''. * The Italo House act [[Don Pablo's Animals]] released a mainly instrumental cover version in 1990. * The Czech band Dunaj recorded a cover version in 1994 * When auditioning for the [[Spice Girls]] in the early '90s, [[Victoria Beckham]] recorded a version of the song for a demo tape, never intending for it to be released, though it has since [[internet leak|leaked onto the Internet]]. * [[Stefanie Sun]] (Simplified Chinese: å­çå§¿; Traditional Chinese: å­«çå§¿), a [[Singapore]]an singer-songwriter, covered the song on her 2002 album ''(Startèªé¸é)'' as well as covers of "[[Hey Jude]]" and "[[Silent All These Years]]". * Various [[hi-NRG]]/[[eurodance]] cover remixes by Obsession was released through [[Almighty Records]] in 2003. Audio samples can be heard on the official Almighty Records website.http://www.almightyrecords.com/product/ALMY163/ * The winner of the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] 2004, [[Ruslana]], has recorded this song. * Norwegian act [[Erlend Ãye]] recorded part of the song in a medley on his album that was part of the ''[[DJ-Kicks]]'' series. * [[No Angels]], first season winners of [[Germany|German]] [[Idol series]] ''[[Popstars]]'', cover it for their 2003 album ''[[Pure (No Angels album)|Pure]]''. This version was used in [[television advertisement|TV spots]] for ladies' [[razor]] ''[[Gillette (brand)|Gillette]] Venus'' * Belgian girl group Seduced recorded a cover which peaked at #25 on the Belgian Singles Top 50 in 2004.http://acharts.us/song/4835 * The Russian children's band Street Magic (Volshebniki Dvora) (ÐÐ¾Ð»ÑÐµÐ±Ð½Ð¸ÐºÐ¸ ÐÐ²Ð¾ÑÐ°) cover the song on their 2005 album ''Hit Parade'' (Ð¥Ð¸Ñ-Ð¿Ð°ÑÐ°Ð´), featuring lead vocals by band member Denis Uzkov (ÐÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð£ÑÐºÐ¾Ð²). * Japanese singer [[Hitomi]] featured a cover as the [[B-side]] to her "Japanese Girl" single in 2005. This version was the theme to commercials for the Gillette Venus razor in 2006 featuring Hitomi on a rock of a lagoon in [[Hawaii]]. * [[Kumi Koda]] recorded the song for Japanese Gillette commercials in 2007, releasing a full cover on her 2009 studio album ''[[Trick (album)|Trick]]''. * Girlband (''[[The X Factor (UK)|The X Factor]]'' UK 2008 finalist) covered the song in the first live show. 2010 Finalists Belle Amie also covered the song in the fourth live show which had a [[Halloween]] theme. * Tom Jones covered the song on album "Classic Tom Jones", released in 1998 * Polish singer [[Dorota Rabczewska|Doda]] covered the song on [[New Year's Eve]] 2009/2010 in [[ÅÃ³dÅº]] ([[Telewizja Polska|TVP2]]). * Lussi Lebrun covered the song during season 8 of ''Nouvelle Star''. * Finnish new wave band [[Belaboris]] covered the song, with Finnish lyrics, on their "...Olpa Kerran" 12" * The song is featured in the stage musical ''[[Priscilla Queen of the Desert â the Musical]]'' * [[Jennifer Lopez]], spokesperson for Venus razors, recorded her own version of the song for "The Venus Goddess Fund for Education". * The Mexican singer NiÃ±el Conde recorded a spanish version of the song, on her new album "Ayer y Hoy", with the same name, Venus. =="Shizgarah", or "Venus" in Russian urban folklore == Despite the fact that the heavily controlled [[Soviet]] [[mass media]] totally ignored much of [[Western culture|Western]] [[popular culture]], the Shocking Blue song quickly become a popular hit in 1970s Russia, especially among street youth akin to Western [[hippie]] and "hooligan" [[subcultures]]. Due to the song's simple arrangement and danceable rhythm, "Venus" was adopted and performed by thousands of [[Resistance movement|underground]] amateur performers, both those who accompanied themselves on acoustic guitar and full contemporary bands who performed it with electric guitar at dance parties. Thus, the English language song of a Dutch band become a prominent phenomenon of Russian urban folklore and was considered by many an unofficial "anthem of the generation". The English language in the song, however, was only very loosely approximated, and the song was not even known by its title, "Venus". A countless number of variants of Russian lyrics existed for this song, but traditionally it was performed using [[gibberish]] or [[scat singing]] phonetically inspired by the sounds of original English lyrics which had become hardly intelligible after being passed along via repeated duplicate copying on cheap, [[low fidelity|low-end]] [[tape recorder]]s. In the Russian variant, the first line of the chorus, "She's got it", was usually pronounced as "Shizgarah" ("Ð¨Ð¸Ð·Ð³Ã¡ÑÐ°") [''sheez-ga'-rah''], and it was this word which became a commonly adopted name of the song in the U.S.S.R., even among those who could understand the original English text. In modern times, few disco clubs and a musical show on [[Nashe Radio]] are named "Shizgarah" after this song. Also, "Shizgarah" ("Ð¨Ð¸Ð·Ð³Ð°ÑÐ°") is a novel of Russian writer [[Sergey Soloukh]] portraying the life of young Soviet hippies in 1970's (http://lib.ru/ZHURNAL/SOLOUH/shizgara.txt). ==Legacy== The Canadian teenage drama series program ''[[Degrassi: The Next Generation]],'' which is known for naming each installment after an 1980s hit song, named a two-part installment after this song. ==References== {{reflist}} {{S-start}} {{succession box | before = "[[I Want You Back]]" by [[The Jackson 5]] | title = [[Billboard Hot 100]] [[List of number-one hits (United States)|number one single]] (Shocking Blue version) | years = February 7, 1970 (one week) | after = "[[Thank You (Falettinme Be Mice Elf Agin)]]"/"[[Everybody Is a Star]]" by [[Sly & the Family Stone]] }} {{succession box | before = "[[Higher Love]]" by [[Steve Winwood]] | title = [[Billboard Hot 100]] [[List of number-one hits (United States)|number-one single]] (Bananarama version) | years = September 6, 1986 (one week) | after = "[[Take My Breath Away]]" by [[Berlin (band)|Berlin]] }} {{succession box | before = "[[Rumors (Timex Social Club song)|Rumors]]" / "Vicious Rumors" by [[Timex Social Club]] | title = [[Hot Dance Club Play|''Billboard'' Hot Dance Club Play]] [[Number-one dance hits of 1986 (USA)|number-one single]] (Bananarama version) | years = August 9, 1986 - August 16, 1986 | after = "[[Ain't Nothin' Goin' on But the Rent]]" by [[Gwen Guthrie]] }} {{succession box | before = "I Wanna Be a Cowboy" by [[Boys Don't Cry (band)|Boys Don't Cry]] | title = [[RIANZ|New Zealand RIANZ Singles Chart]] number-one single (Bananarama version) | years = September 12, 1986 -
